document.title: Indiana Academic Standards for Social Studies: Kindergarten

7B17998BBB3A42E1A28ACB5808A13A17.description: Give examples of work activities that people do at home.

BF85B5360C23455194C79268D92A63E7.description: Explain why people in a community choose different jobs.
comments: Example: People may have different types of jobs because they like doing different things or because they are better at doing one particular type of job

4EA88F6E34C543568B8C129B700A9C01.description: Identify and describe different kinds of jobs that people do and the tools or equipment used in these jobs.
comments: Example: Use picture books, stories and software programs/games to illustrate and identify different types of jobs, as well as tools and materials used in different jobs.

6C976AD8312E48A68EBE94B5D22254B4.description: Explain that people work to earn money to buy the things they want and need.

251F6C6E2E4445AAB138BB57E950706F.description: Economics: Students explain that people do different jobs and work to meet basic economic wants and needs.

5D1B94A07788469ABF4959D054F4C3C6.description: Recommend ways that people can improve their environment at home, in school, and in the neighborhood.

D9C2A0E6A3A04477957E6914CAE103BA.description: Identify and compare similarities and differences in families, classmates, neighbors and neighborhoods, and ethnic and cultural groups.
comments: Example: Use newspapers, yearbooks, local Web sites and photographs to show the similarities and differences in family customs and celebrations, clothing, houses, work, and cultural and ethnic heritage.

ABDB134CB0284837AAFD567F6F4CE574.description: Describe and give examples of seasonal weather changes and illustrate how weather affects people and the environment.
comments: Example: In different seasons, people wear different kinds of clothing.

2F93D947CF824649B3A46834E8F5B2E1.description: Identify and describe the address and location of school; understand the importance of an address.

B3608661285C4DC3AEA44648258971AF.description: Locate and describe places in the school and community.
comments: Example: Cafeteria, library, office, restrooms, gym and the fire station

994524029D8E4A6380F41D9C5F09529C.description: Identify maps and globes as ways of representing Earth and understand the basic difference between a map and globe.

DBEE9002D5694A54B636A5FE59499356.description: Use words related to location, direction and distance, including here/there, over/under, left/right, above/below, forward/backward and between.
comments: Example: Give and follow simple navigational directions such as walk forward ten steps, turn right and walk between the desks.

629960F0D2AD4537A6A7D803B7A8C2A7.description: Geography: Students understand that maps and globes are different representations of the Earth's surface and begin to explore the physical and human geographic characteristics of their school, neighborhood and community.

28B4C276B8C040E598DBBB5ECC259062.description: Give examples of how to be a responsible family member and member of a group.
comments: Example: Respecting the property and rights of others, being honest and truthful, and respecting authority* *authority: power that people have the right to use because of custom or law

79CE0E20B42440C5ACC698790C7F34FA.description: Give examples of classroom and school rules and explain the importance of following these rules to ensure order and safety.

EA540902D79E4194A06B31E6CB3C7130.description: Identify and explain that the President of the United States is the leader of our country and that the American flag is a symbol of the United States.

61E8DD5DB4374FA687EA24052796631F.description: Give examples of people who are community helpers and leaders and describe how they help us.
comments: Example: Parents, teachers, school principal, bus drivers and policemen

C99EA734D7424ED982CCADC448628AD5.description: Civics and Government: Students learn that they are citizens of their school, community and the United States; identify symbols of the nation; and understand the importance of being a responsible citizen who knows why rules are needed and follows them.

comments: Example: Use a calendar to identify days of the week and school activities and birthdays.
B6EAB56990F74B069F0A1EEB1B28A205.description: Explain that calendars are used to represent the days of the week and months of the year

1EBB1D96BA224E76BF7289455127E5C7.description: Identify and order events that takes place in a sequence.
comments: Example: Identify events in the school day as first, next, last, yesterday, today and tomorrow; place school events in order.

8CCBBABE21F447EC8E57A05E1D125B72.description: Identify people, celebrations, commemorations, and holidays as a way of honoring people, heritage, and events.
comments: Example: George Washington; Chief Little Turtle; Abraham Lincoln, Harriet Tubman; and Martin Luther King, Jr., Thanksgiving, Columbus Day, Grandparent's Day, and birthdays.

21FEF9AC930C4429AD4C0AB3AF5EC626.description: Compare children and families of today with those from the past.
comments: Example: Compare clothing, houses, and other objects.

7CB18A01A155483B9F7B37A84E4B6601.description: History: Students examine the connections of their own environment with the past, begin to distinguish between events and people of the past and the present, and use a sense of time in classroom planning and participation.
